Gay Liberation means to become free from a society which discriminates against someone or people because of their sexual orientation.

Members of the Gay Liberation Army seek to create an independent, gay-run state on the west coast between San Francisco and Los Angeles. It will be called "Homotopia" and it's government would be run a lot like Quebec wants theirs: all the benefits of being part of the larger country, but the ability to make their own laws and regulations. The problem is that there will be no internal population growth.

I think as much as possible should be done to ensure gays are given equal opportunity in the workplace. At the same time, gays need to realize that this is as much a behavioral issue as anything. Businesses have to protect their profits because it helps eveyone, including the gay person who works there. I think if a gay person can go to work, do his job, get along with his co-workers and work a normal productive work day without presenting a lot of distractions for everyone because he is gay then that's great, and there shouldn't be a problem. But gay pride as a political movement has no business in the workplace. If an employer was upset that a gay employee was using the workplace for that sort of thing, I can't say I would blame him for being upset. In an ideal situation, no one would be able to really tell who was gay and who was not at first impression with anyone at work.

 I happen to do some consulting for an ultra conservative religious run healthcare organization. 
 Most of my co-workers know I'm gay, heck my partner works there full-time as a finance manager...but it's simply not talked about. Neither my partner or I get "domestic partner" benefits, which sucks because my position at the company doesn't offer benefits of anykind. We don't have a "gay network" and we don't sponsor any "pride events." 
 As a matter of fact they're so conservative that they actually observe the "Sabbath." 
 In the winter everyone in non-patient contact positions must be out of their offices no later than one hour before sunset. 
 It's kinda strange that way, but at least their fairly liberal with their "eto" or "pto" which includes sick-days an vacation time. But it still sucks when they have "family" events and my son and I have to actually PAY because we're not legally seen as "family." Sometimes my partner's boss will toss an occassional cookie her way and let her put my son down as her "dependent" for some of these events. 
 
 But it's still not completely fair. She or I could infact be fired at anytime if anyone at corporate level found out about our relationship. Even though it's not legal to do so in our state, this company is actaully exempt because it's a religious run organization. They can fein the excuse that their religion prohibits them from employing gays and/or lesbians. Granted, I don't think it would happen, but it is always a possibility we are all too aware of.

Even though it's not legal to do so in our state, this company is actaully exempt because it's a religious run organization. They can fein the excuse that their religion prohibits them from employing gays and/or lesbians. Granted, I don't think it would happen, but it is always a possibility we are all too aware of.

 
 If they are exempt, then they aren't a company. They have to be non-profit. They probably ARE religious-affiliated. The bottom line is that if you don't like it badly enough, you don't have to do work for them. They are free to run it as they see fit, and you are free to not work for them.
 
 Re. politics, employers not allowing political work to be done on company time is not something limited to conservatives. It's simply a matter of expecting your employees to not use the workplace for political advertising.

Re. politics, employers not allowing political work to be done on 
 company time is not something limited to conservatives.

 
 Who ever said anything about "political work to be done?" Simply having a political type sticker or sign doesn't quite constitute "work" for such cause. It's simply showing something which is of a personal nature. 
 If you actually believe the two are the same, well that answers quite a bit about you and your thought processes. Not to mention the transparency of your supposed "support" for gay/lesbian employees. 
 Yet another item which comes as no suprise to anyone here.
 
 
 It's simply a 
 matter of expecting your employees to not use the workplace for political 
 advertising.

 
 Putting a political sticker up in one's cubicle is a FAR CRY from putting up a political pettition in a common area. Again, you show your bigotry in small enough doses to fool only you.
 
 
 ...and yes, I still have you on ignore, I used the email delivery notification that was sent as my quotes.

...and yes, I still have you on ignore, I used the email delivery notification that was sent as my quotes.

 
 Kinda defeats the purpose, huh?

Would they let you put up a big "W" sign in the door of your office (assuming you have one), or a pro-life message sign? Or are they just one-sided in what they allow with their politics?

 
 Honestly I have no idea. Political messages are pretty nuetral around here. But they don't consider Pride and the open acceptance of homosexuals a political comment. It is part of my company's very serious committment to diversity. They also offer domestic partner benefits and treat the homosexual community as a market group - and one they try to target.
 
 For the record there are also Latino, Women, Black, Native, Christian, and Jewish employee networks. Any group can form a network - they just have provide proof of interest and a senior sponsor. We frequently win awards as one of the top companies to work at for women, people of color and homosexuals.
 
 Justine - I am lucky.

 From the amount of time and the times of the day that jyoshu devotes to spreading the anti-gay industry propoganda, one can only assume that:
 
 A) jyoshu is unemployed and has LOTS of free time on his hands. (If so, how can he afford the expense of 24/7/365 Internet connection, month after month after month?)
 
 or
